text: mass shootings marred July 4th
celebrations leaving many communities in
the United States devastated and
President Biden will host the prime
minister of Sweden ahead of the NATO
Summit good morning I'm Windsor Johnston
from NPR news and here are today's top
stories this week's mass shootings in
Philadelphia Pennsylvania and Fort Worth
Texas were among several mass shootings
that marred July 4th celebrations Across
the Nation NPR's redu Chatterjee reports
gun violence has been claiming lives in
record numbers in the U.S leaving many
communities dealing with trauma and
grief nearly 350 mass shootings have
already happened this year more than 21
000 people have died from all kinds of
gun violence many more are left
struggling with the mental health
Fallout of such violence While most
people recover in time psychologist
Robin gurwich at Duke University says
people closest to the incident suffer
the most those that were close to where
the event happened or if they had fear
for themselves or loved ones or knew
anyone that was killed or injured they
have more risk for mental health
challenges but she adds long-term mental
health and social support can help
communities heal in the long run Ritu
Chatterjee NPR news President Biden will
host the prime minister of Sweden at the
White House today NPR's Diva shivaram
reports the visit comes ahead of the
upcoming NATO Summit this month an
alliance that Sweden has been trying to
join as a result of Russia's invasion of
Ukraine the White House says the meeting
between Biden and Swedish prime minister
Ulf christusson will reaffirm America's
view that Sweden should join NATO as
soon as possible since Russia's invasion
of Ukraine Finland and Sweden have both
moved to join NATO but only finland's
application has been ratified so far to
hold up on confirming Sweden's
membership is due to opposition from
Turkey the White House says during their
meeting Biden and Christensen will also
discuss relations with China climate
change and new technologies Deepa
shivaram NPR news Ukraine is once again
warning of the threat posed to the
zaparitia nuclear power plant by
occupying Russian forces speaking
through a BBC interpreter Ukrainian
President philodamir zielinski says the
Kremlin is planning dangerous
provocations at the facility
we have information from our
intelligence that on the roof of several
power units of this operation nuclear
power plant the Russian military
installed objects similar to explosives
the world sees that the only source of
danger for this operation nuclear power
plant is Russia itself and no one else
Russian troop seized the station last
year since then the two side have
accused the other of shelling around the
facility and risking a major nuclear
mishap
you're listening to NPR news in
Washington
